Ferrariunveils2026liveryof499PsettodefendFIAWECworldtitles Ferrari¬†unveils¬†2026¬†livery¬†of¬†499P¬†set¬†to¬†defend¬†FIA¬†WEC¬†world¬†titles Ferrari has officially launched the 2026 season, which will see the Prancing Horse return to the FIA World Endurance Championship to defend the Manufacturers‚Äô and Drivers‚Äô world titles secured in an unforgettable and already historic 2025 campaign. Global Banking Annual Review 2025 shows how a targeted approach can help them thrive. SoundCloud Widget ### DOWNLOADS ![](https://www.mckinsey.com/~/media/mckinsey/industries/financial%20services/our%20insights/global%20banking%20annual%20review/why-precision-not-heft-defines-the-future-of-banking-new_thumbnail.jpeg) ##### Global Banking Annual Review 2025: Why precision, not heft, defines the future of banking [Full Report (59 pages)](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/global-banking-annual-review#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Ffinancial%20services%2Four%20insights%2Fglobal%20banking%20annual%20review%2Fwhy-precision-not-heft-defines-the-future-of-banking-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse) Ask McKinsey Ask McKinsey **One would be forgiven** for assuming that the past few years have been mediocre for banking, given headlines about layoffs and worries about an economic slowdown. In reality, banks have racked up record after record without much fanfare or notice. Byline ## About the authors This report is a collaborative effort by [Darius Imregun](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/darius-imregun), [Ido Segev](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/ido-segev), [Jon Steitz](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/jon-steitz), [Klaus Dallerup](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/klaus-dallerup), Marti Riba, [Mikl√≥s Dietz](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/miklos-dietz), [Pradip Patiath](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/pradip-patiath), and [Saptarshi Ganguly](https://www.mckinsey.com/our-people/saptarshi-ganguly), with Michael Kirchner, Suhas Gudhe, and Valeria Laszlo, representing views from McKinsey‚Äôs Financial Services Practice. Between 2019 and 2024, funds intermediated by the global banking system, including traditional banks and nonbank providers, grew by $122 trillion, or about 40 percent, propelled by the global wealth of households and institutions. Banks‚Äô revenues after risk cost reached a record $5.5 trillion in 2024, helping push the sector‚Äôs net income to $1.2 trillion, the highest total ever for any industry. Yet capital markets remain skeptical about banks‚Äô value creation potential: Valuation of the banking sector trails the average of all other industries by nearly 70 percent. Why the disconnect? Banks‚Äô recent performance has been buoyed by favorable conditions‚Äîa peak in the global wealth cycle, unusually strong revenue margins boosted by higher interest rates, and low risk costs‚Äîbut these tailwinds are dissipating. ROE is barely clearing the cost of capital. The industry‚Äôs price-to-book ratio is 1, 67 percent below the average for other industries. Chapter 1 ## The peak before the plateau [The peak before the plateau](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/financial-services/our-insights/global-banking-annual-review\#) After the peaks of the past few years, the banking sector may experience a reversion to the mean, with slower growth and mounting pressure on profitability. To catch the next growth curve, banks must shift from relying on traditional, time-worn approaches to precision strategies that generate value in more challenging conditions. Different scenarios are possible, of course, depending on macroeconomic, technological, and regulatory outcomes. But the long-term pressures weighing on the sector are clear. The likely reversion to the mean will be driven not just by macroeconomic factors, such as interest rate movements and demographic shifts, but also by disruption stemming from advancements in AI, intensifying competition from nonbank providers such as fintechs, and evolving customer expectations. > To catch the next growth curve, banks must shift from relying on traditional, time-worn approaches to precision strategies that generate value in more challenging conditions. Existing strategies haven‚Äôt succeeded. Banks spend about $600 billion a year on technology but productivity remains low. Broad customer segmentation hasn‚Äôt brought results. In capital efficiency, sweeping reallocations and broad balance sheet adjustments are insufficient. Chasing M&A deals to achieve scale and nothing else hasn‚Äôt delivered. To thrive, banks need new solutions. Macro-focused, scale-driven strategies once promised resilience but no longer suffice. Precision is the decisive differentiator, separating leading banks from slow movers and reshaping the industry‚Äôs performance curve. The ‚Äúprecision toolbox,‚Äù applicable to banks of any size, revamps strategy across four core dimensions: ##### How relevant and useful is this article for you? ### Most Popular Insights 1. OpenAI said Wednesday that it‚Äôs acquiring Jony Ive‚Äôs AI devices startup io for about $6.4 billion. - The deal is all in stock and the value includes OpenAI‚Äôs current stake in the company. - It‚Äôs by far OpenAI‚Äôs largest acquisition to date and comes just weeks after the company agreed to buy AI-assisted coding tool Windsurf for $3 billion. (Photo by Jason Redmond / AFP) (Photo by JASON REDMOND/AFP via Getty Images)](https://image.cnbcfm.com/api/v1/image/108147623-1747681699963-gettyimages-2215434286-AFP_47CH4D9.jpeg?v=1749497716&w=1858&h=1045&vtcrop=y) OpenAI CEO Sam Altman appears on screen during a talk with Microsoft Chair and CEO Satya Nadella at the Microsoft Build 2025 conference in Seattle on May 19, 2025. Jason Redmond \| AFP \| Getty Images OpenAI said Wednesday that it‚Äôs buying Jony Ive‚Äôs AI devices startup io for about $6.4 billion in an all-equity deal that pushes the artificial intelligence company firmly into the world of hardware. Ive is taking on ‚Äúdeep creative and design responsibilities across OpenAI and io,‚Äù the company said in a statement. OpenAI said io is coming in-house, while Ive and his ‚Äúcreative collective‚Äù called LoveFrom will stay independent. In a [blog post](https://openai.com/sam-and-jony/) Wednesday, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Ive said that io was founded a year ago by Ive, along with Apple alumni Scott Cannon, Tang Tan and Evans Hankey, who briefly took over Ive‚Äôs role at Apple after he departed. ‚ÄúThe io team, focused on developing products that inspire, empower and enable, will now merge with OpenAI to work more intimately with the research, engineering and product teams in San Francisco,‚Äù the post said. OpenAI said it‚Äôs paying $5 billion in the transaction, as it already owns 23% of the company. Altman wrote in a [post on X](https://x.com/sama/status/1925242282523103408) that he believes Ive is ‚Äúthe greatest designer in the world.‚Äù The purchase is by far OpenAI‚Äôs largest and comes weeks after the company agreed to buy AI-assisted coding tool [Windsurf](https://www.cnbc.com/2025/04/17/openai-looked-at-cursor-before-considering-deal-with-rival-windsurf.html) for $3 billion. Prior to that, OpenAI acquired analytics database company [Rockset](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/06/21/openai-acquires-database-analytics-firm-rockset.html) for an undisclosed sum in 2024. Ive announced in 2019 that he was [leaving Apple](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/27/apple-chief-design-officer-jony-ive-most-iconic-products.html), where he was the longtime chief design officer, to start LoveFrom. Airbnb said [in 2020](https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/21/airbnb-teaming-up-with-former-apple-design-boss-jony-ive.html) that Ive was consulting with the company on hiring and future products. The New York Times [reported](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/21/technology/jony-ive-apple-lovefrom.html) last year that LoveFrom‚Äôs clients pay the firm up to $200 million a year and that its designers at the time were working on projects for Christie‚Äôs, Airbnb and Ferrari. LoveFrom says on its website that it was founded by Ive and designer Marc Newson, but it doesn‚Äôt say anything about what the company does or include any mention of io. Apple chief design officer Jony Ive (L) and Apple CEO Tim Cook inspect the new iPhone XR during an Apple special event at the Steve Jobs Theatre on September 12, 2018 in Cupertino, California. Justin Sullivan \| Getty Images News \| Getty Images Ive is responsible for designing [Apple](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AAPL/)‚Äôs most iconic products, including the iPod, iPhone, iPad and MacBook Air. He also helped design Apple‚Äôs new Cupertino headquarters, called Apple Park, a project that began in 2004, with the campus officially opening in 2019. News of the acquisition comes as OpenAI, which was recently valued at $300 billion in a¬†[funding round](https://www.cnbc.com/2025/03/31/openai-closes-40-billion-in-funding-the-largest-private-fundraise-in-history-softbank-chatgpt.html)¬†led by SoftBank, is rushing to stay ahead in the generative AI race, where competitors including¬†[Google](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/GOOGL/), Anthropic and¬†[Elon Musk‚Äôs](https://www.cnbc.com/elon-musk/)¬†xAI are investing heavily and regularly rolling out new products. Part of staying ahead in that race includes shoring up its hardware operations. To further its hardware ambitions, OpenAI [hired](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/11/05/openai-hires-metas-former-orion-head-to-lead-its-robotics-efforts.html) the former head of [Meta‚Äôs](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/META/) Orion augmented reality glasses initiative in November to lead its robotics and consumer hardware efforts. Caitlin ‚ÄúCK‚Äù Kalinowski wrote in an announcement at the time that the role would ‚Äúinitially focus on OpenAI‚Äôs robotics work and partnerships to help bring AI into the physical world and unlock its benefits for humanity.‚Äù Also in November, [OpenAI invested in Physical Intelligence](https://www.cnbc.com/2024/11/04/jeff-bezos-and-openai-invest-in-robot-startup-physical-intelligence.html), a robot startup based in San Francisco, which raised $400 million at a $2.4 billion valuation. Other investors included¬†[Amazon](https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/AMZN/)¬†founder Jeff Bezos. The startup focuses on ‚Äúbringing general-purpose AI into the physical world,‚Äù according to its website, by developing large-scale AI models and algorithms to power robots. **WATCH:** [Ive and Altman teaming up](https://www.cnbc.com/video/2024/09/23/former-apple-exec-jony-ive-partners-with-openais-sam-altman- ### SOURCE 6 URL: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/shell-fuels-future-deal-ferrari-173249878.html Oops, something went wrong [Skip to navigation](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/shell-fuels-future-deal-ferrari-173249878.html#navigation-container) [Skip to main content](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/shell-fuels-future-deal-ferrari-173249878.html#nimbus-app) [Skip to right column](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/shell-fuels-future-deal-ferrari-173249878.html#right-rail) [![Benzinga](https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/HizwK5zYqX0sSg12CHlHfg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTE5NDtoPTQ4O2NmPXdlYnA-/https://s.yimg.com/os/creatr-uploaded-images/2020-11/f4b4e310-2b77-11eb-afee-ca1478f0e9ef)](http://www.benzinga.com/ "Benzinga") # Shell Fuels The Future: New Deal with Ferrari And Power Plant Acquisition On The Horizon ![Shell Fuels The Future: New Deal with Ferrari And Power Plant Acquisition On The Horizon](https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/eK.BDe68E_XgJ3oiNIkVzg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTk2MDtoPTU0MDtjZj13ZWJw/https://media.zenfs.com/en/Benzinga/7fafaaf37906b8d913c728896f39ba34) Shell Fuels The Future: New Deal with Ferrari And Power Plant Acquisition On The Horizon Lekha Gupta October 23, 20242 min read [RACE \\ +0.76%](https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/RACE/ "RACE") **Ferrari N.V.**(NYSE: [RACE](http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=RACE)) disclosed a multi-year renewal of its partnership with **Shell PLC** (NYSE: [SHEL](http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=SHEL)). Since 2019, the North American subsidiary has maintained a contract with RISEC under an energy conversion agreement for 100% of the plant‚Äôs energy offtake. The transaction is pending regulatory approvals and is anticipated to close in the first quarter of 2025. Huibert Vigeveno, Shell Downstream, Renewables & Energy Solutions Director, stated, ‚ÄúShell has had a successful integrated gas and power business in the growing ISO New England market for over 20 years, and this acquisition secures valuable trading opportunities by guaranteeing SENA‚Äôs position in the market.‚Äù ‚ÄúOur strong understanding of this plant‚Äôs performance positions Shell to capitalise on its value within our existing trading portfolio.‚Äù This month, Shell raised its third-quarter upstream production outlook to 1,740-1,840 thousand boe/d [, boosting investor confidence](https://www.benzinga.com/markets/equities/24/10/41207230/shell-raises-q3-upstream-production-outlook-revises-integrated-gas-guidance?utm_campaign=partner_feed&utm_source=yahooFinance&utm_medium=partner_feed&utm_content=site&nid=41497086). ## At a Glance - Updated December 22, 2025: July-November 2025 layoffs added. This tracker began recording tech job losses in January 2024, documenting an initial wave of layoffs framed as a necessary post-COVID correction. Companies that had aggressively hired IT professionals to meet pandemic-era ¬†demand began shedding roles to offset over-hiring and brace for a possible economic slowdown. In 2025, the underlying reasons for layoffs evolved. The 2025 wave of job cuts, which began around mid-year, were less about fixing past over-hiring and more about a major, strategic restructuring. This phase was driven by two main factors: continued economic pressures and the rapid adoption of AI. Companies were restructuring to cut costs and move resources and hiring budgets to support AI development and automation. The data compiled from June 2025 onward showed the industry is moving away from rapid growth and focusing on efficiency as it invests in AI. The latter half of 2025 saw a steady displacement of workers, with more than 60,000 jobs cut between June and November. Most notable was the large-scale restructuring at legacy tech giants like Intel, Microsoft and Amazon, where leadership explicitly linked layoffs to cost-cutting and a pivot toward AI-centric operations. These cuts highlight the technology's dual impact: AI is not only reshaping core engineering functions but also replacing human labor in easily automated tasks and data-heavy support functions. In this space, InformationWeek will document some of the more significant layoffs, updated regularly. Be sure to check back. Here's a look at the biggest tech layoffs so far: - [November 2025 Tech Layoffs](https://www.informationweek.com/it-leadership/tech-company-layoffs-the-covid-tech-bubble-bursts-sep-14#November%202025%20Tech%20Layoffs) -
